docs.abstract: Shows that defied categorization offered a stark choice: Escape an angry world, or face up to its travails. Beyond Broadway, writers explored race, inequality and addiction.
docs.snippet: Shows that defied categorization offered a stark choice: Escape an angry world, or face up to its travails. Beyond Broadway, writers explored race, inequality and addiction.
docs.lead_paragraph: Escape or confront? In a year when news of an angry, snarling nation seemed way too much with us, 24 hours a day, the New York theater served up both forget-your-troubles fantasies and magnifying mirrors to a world seriously out of joint.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Is This a Room: Reality Winner Verbatim Transcription (Play)

byline.original: By Ben Brantley, Jesse Green, Laura Collins-Hughes, Alexis Soloski and Elisabeth Vincentelli

docs.abstract: A new guard of black quarterbacks is leading the N.F.L. but as 100 years of history have shown — from Fritz Pollard to Colin Kaepernick — the league has always needed a push to make progress.
docs.snippet: A new guard of black quarterbacks is leading the N.F.L. but as 100 years of history have shown — from Fritz Pollard to Colin Kaepernick — the league has always needed a push to make progress.
docs.lead_paragraph: The explosion of young black quarterbacks with phenomenal athletic ability and passing acumen has become the rage of the N.F.L. As defenses in the league have become more athletic, offenses have made an adjustment at the sport’s most important position.

headline.main: The N.F.L.’s Embrace of Black Players Has Always Been Conditional
headline.print_headline: The N.F.L.’s Embrace of Black Players Has Always Been Conditional

docs.abstract: Jamar Roberts, the company’s first resident choreographer, wants to bring the world into his dances.
docs.snippet: Jamar Roberts, the company’s first resident choreographer, wants to bring the world into his dances.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes riding the subway has its upside. It affords time to think — and, in the case of Jamar Roberts, to choreograph. Recently, as he headed to the final working rehearsal for “Ode,” his new dance at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, he had to think about what it was missing: an ending.

headline.main: At Alvin Ailey, a Quiet Disrupter With No Time for Tears
headline.print_headline: Disrupter Doesn’t Have Time for Tears

keywords.value: When They Call You a Terrorist: A Black Lives Matter Memoir (Book)

docs.abstract: Readers discuss how today’s audiences should view classic operas from another era that have offensive stereotypes.
docs.snippet: Readers discuss how today’s audiences should view classic operas from another era that have offensive stereotypes.

headline.main: What to Do About Racism in Opera?
headline.print_headline: What to Do About Racism in Opera?

docs.abstract: Who says pop culture has become too safe?
docs.snippet: Who says pop culture has become too safe?
docs.lead_paragraph: I left a recent matinee of “Queen & Slim,” the mesmerizing new outlaw romance directed by Melina Matsoukas, astonished on two levels. The film itself kept me rapt; I cried through the end and left the theater with the dazed, disoriented feeling you get when a movie makes you momentarily forget everything else in your life. But as amazed as I was by the experience of watching the film, I was equally amazed that it got made at all.

docs.abstract: America in the 2010s saw significant cultural and political shifts that pushed us forward.
docs.snippet: America in the 2010s saw significant cultural and political shifts that pushed us forward.
docs.lead_paragraph: America is always in a state of flux. The country is an eternal experiment, aiming at evolution, betting on its own betterment.

headline.main: The Decade We Changed Our Minds
headline.print_headline: The Decade  We Changed  Our Minds

docs.abstract: Paul Skalnik is a grifter and criminal. Now a man may be executed because of his dubious testimony. Why did prosecutors rely on him as an informant?
docs.snippet: Paul Skalnik is a grifter and criminal. Now a man may be executed because of his dubious testimony. Why did prosecutors rely on him as an informant?
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is a partnership between ProPublica, where Pamela Colloff is a senior reporter, and The New York Times Magazine, where she is a staff writer.

headline.main: How This Con Man’s Wild Testimony Sent Dozens to Jail, and 4 to Death Row

docs.abstract: Special screenings and performances of black films and plays tailored for black audiences can feel especially welcoming.
docs.snippet: Special screenings and performances of black films and plays tailored for black audiences can feel especially welcoming.
docs.lead_paragraph: A handful of playwrights, directors, filmmakers and film lovers have created spaces for black audiences to crack jokes and clap back without apology and, afterward, process complex, nuanced race-related issues.

headline.main: At ‘Black Out’ Performances, the Power of Healing Through Community
headline.print_headline: The Healing Power of a Black Audience

docs.abstract: More movies and shows are imagining worlds where prejudice is seemingly nonexistent and everyone is accepted.
docs.snippet: More movies and shows are imagining worlds where prejudice is seemingly nonexistent and everyone is accepted.
docs.lead_paragraph: When I contemplate what my ideal world might look like, I imagine one in which everyone just minds their business and does their own thing, so long as they aren’t causing any harm — directly or indirectly — to others. That doesn’t mean there isn’t conflict or that bad things never happen: Humans will still annoy one another and argue, many marriages will still end in divorce, studio execs will still make up excuses to tell the same story about Batman or Batman-adjacent characters for the hundredth time.

docs.abstract: Harassment has long been a hurdle on the anchorwoman’s rise to the top. New projects, like “The Morning Show” and “Bombshell,” examine what she has to do to stay there.
docs.snippet: Harassment has long been a hurdle on the anchorwoman’s rise to the top. New projects, like “The Morning Show” and “Bombshell,” examine what she has to do to stay there.
docs.lead_paragraph: “The Morning Show” begins with a wake-up call. Mitch Kessler (Steve Carell), the Matt Lauer-ish co-host of a “Today” show-ish program, answers the phone at 3 a.m. to learn that he has been fired over allegations of sexual misconduct. When his co-host, Alex Levy (Jennifer Aniston), reports to a chaotic pre-dawn set, her producer, Chip (Mark Duplass), says something sycophantic about how much America needs her, and she snaps. “Don’t drag America into this,” she says. “This affects me.”
